facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 152 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 152 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 4, 1962 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Criminal Appeal No. 505 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 4, 1962 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Criminal Appeal No. 505 of 1961.

facts.text: Hearing date August 29, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: August 29, 1963. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-This appeal by special leave is against a conviction

facts.text: Appellant convicted and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 by Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is against a conviction and sentence under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878. The appellant was acquitted by the trial court, but on appeal by the State of Rajasthan, the Rajasthan High Court set aside the order of acquittal and convicted the appellant under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for one year.

facts.text: Trial court acquitted the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was acquitted by the trial court, but on appeal by the State of Rajasthan, the Rajasthan High Court set aside the order of acquittal

facts.text: Lal Singh, Sub-Inspector of the Check-post of Barmer, followed the appellant into a railway train at Luni railway station.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that on receipt of some information that gold smuggled from Pakistan was being carried, Lal Singh, Sub-Inspector of the Check-post of Barmer, followed the appellant into a railway train at Luni railway station, and in the running train between the stations of Kerla and Pali, searched appellants person

facts.text: Searched appellant's person in running train between Kerla and Pali stations and found 286 tolas of gold in a pouli under his trousers.

anchor.surface_text: followed the appellant into a railway train at Luni railway station, and in the running train between the stations of Kerla and Pali, searched appellants person and found that he was carrying 286 tolas of gold in a pouli under his trousers.

facts.text: Gold consisted of six blocks bearing marks 999, N. M. Rothschild Sons, 22 bars bearing marks 999, 3 small pieces of gold and one pair of murkies.

anchor.surface_text: In the reasonable belief that these were smuggled goods, Lal Singh seized the gold. The gold that was seized consisted of six blocks bearing marks 999, N. M. Rothschild Sons, 22 bars bearing marks 999, 3 small pieces of gold and one pair of murkies.

facts.text: Lal Singh seized the gold after preparing a seizure list in the presence of witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Lal Singh seized the gold after preparing a seizure list in the presence of witnesses and later produced the appellant along with the gold before the Superintendent, Land Customs, Barmer.

facts.text: Produced appellant along with gold before Superintendent, Land Customs, Barmer.

anchor.surface_text: and later produced the appellant along with the gold before the Superintendent, Land Customs, Barmer.

facts.text: Collector of Customs, New Delhi order dated July 19, 1957 confiscated the gold and imposed fine of Rs. 10,000 on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the Collector of Customs, New Delhi, dated July 19,1957, this gold was confiscated and a fine of Rs. 10,000 was imposed on the appellant.

facts.text: Criminal proceedings instituted against appellant for offence under s. 167(81) Sea Customs Act after confiscation.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal proceedings were afterwards instituted against the appellant on the allegation that he had committed an offence under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act.

facts.text: Main defence: no gold recovered from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The main defence of the accused, who pleaded not guilty, was that no gold was recovered from him.

facts.text: Trial court held prosecution failed to establish recovery of gold from accused.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that the prosecution had failed to establish the recovery of gold from the accused.

facts.text: Trial court accepted defence that Lal Singh had no authority to search and seize at the place.

anchor.surface_text: It further accepted the defence contention that Lal Singh had no authority to search the appellant and seize the gold at the place where the seizure was alleged to have been made.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court set aside acquittal and convicted appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the Rajasthan High Court set aside the order of acquittal and convicted the appellant under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for one year.

facts.text: High Court held Lal Singh had authority to seize and s.178-A applies.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to contrary findings on all these points. It held that the evidence of Lal Singh as regards the seizure should be believed and that the seizure of the gold from the accused had been proved satisfactorily. It was also of the opinion that Lal Singh had authority to seize the gold at the place where the seizure was made, and that s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act applied.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted Lal Singh's testimony on seizure.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of Lal Singhs evidence along with the evidence of appellants own witness, Poonam Chand we are convinced that the story of recovery of gold from the accused is true.

facts.text: Seizure memo Exh. P.3 mentions three witnesses including Pukh Raj son of Awasthi Mal.

anchor.surface_text: The seizure Memo. which he claimed to have prepared at the time of the seizure was marked Exh. P. 3. This document mentions the names of three persons as search witnesses. ... The third name mentioned in Exh. P. 3 is Pukh Raj son of Awasthi Mal, aged about 22 years, resident of Ajit.

facts.text: Defence examined Pukh Raj son of Basti Mal, resident of Ajit, claiming to be the only one.

anchor.surface_text: The defence examined a Pukh Raj who gave his fathers name as Basti Mal and who was resident of Ajit, and stated that he was the only Pukh Raj in that village.

facts.text: Poonam Chand (defence witness) spoke of search in compartment enroute Luni to Pali, no gold from Hukma Ram but purse recovered.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be noticed that the defence witness No. 2, Poonam Chand, has also spoken about the search. His evidence is that police conducted search in the compartment when the train was enroute from Luni to Pali, and that the police took search of the accused Hukma present before the court and of two or three more persons named Kesrimal and Tarachand.

facts.text: Notification appoints officers of Rajasthan Civil Police and Armed Constabulary of and above Head Constable in specified districts as Land Customs Officers within jurisdiction of Collector Land Customs Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by Sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Land Customs Act 1924 (19 of 1924) read with the notification of the Government of India in the late Finance Deptt. Central Revenues No. 5444, dated 1st December 1924, the Central Board of Revenue hereby appoints for the areas adjoining the Land Customs Frontiers separating West Pakistan from India, the officers of the Government of Rajasthan specified in the schedule hereto annexed, to be Land Customs Officers within the jurisdiction of the Collector of Land Customs Delhi.

facts.text: Lal Singh is officer in District of Barmer.

anchor.surface_text: Lal Singh, being an officer in the District of Barmer which is mentioned in the Schedule, was an officer for the entire area

facts.text: Supreme Court held Lal Singh had authority to seize at the place.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the construction put by the High Court on the notification is right, and Lai Singh, being an officer in the District of Barmer which is mentioned in the Schedule, was an officer for the entire area which formed the jurisdiction of the Collector of Land Customs, Delhi, including the place where the seizure was made, and was therefore competent to make the seizure.

facts.text: Gold quantity 286 tolas and 11 annas, about three kilograms.

anchor.surface_text: The total quantity was as much as 286 tolas and 11 annas, that is, about three kilograms.

facts.text: Appellant is a pointsman in the Railway.

anchor.surface_text: a pointsman of the Railway, not expected to have so much gold in his possession

facts.text: Supreme Court found accused carried gold knowingly with intent to evade prohibition on gold import.

anchor.surface_text: all these circumstances establish beyond a shadow of doubt that accused was carrying the gold knowingly and with the intention of evading the prohibition that was in force with respect to the import of gold into the country.

facts.text: Prosecution claimed burden under s.178-A on accused to prove gold not smuggled.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution claimed that under s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act, the burden of proving that gold was not smuggled lay on the accused.

facts.text: High Court found accused failed to prove gold not smuggled.

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the High Court, the accused had failed to prove that the gold was not smuggled and that under the provisions of s. 178-A as also on the evidence in the case, the gold had been established to be smuggled gold.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal upholding conviction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court has rightly held that all the ingredients of the offence under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act have been established.

under s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent assessment of Lal Singh's detailed testimony corroborated by defense witness Poonam Chand confirming search in compartment; no cross-examination suggestion of other searches; implausible to falsely implicate appellant over real culprit; enmity claim unsubstantiated; search witnesses likely gained over.

holdings.text: the construction put by the High Court on the notification is right, and Lai Singh, being an officer in the District of Barmer which is mentioned in the Schedule, was an officer for the entire area which formed the jurisdiction of the Collector of Land Customs, Delhi, including the place where the seizure was made, and was therefore competent to make the seizure

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the construction put by the High Court on the notification is right, and Lai Singh, being an officer in the District of Barmer which is mentioned in the Schedule, was an officer for the entire area which formed the jurisdiction of the Collector of Land Customs, Delhi, including the place where the seizure was made, and was therefore competent to make the seizure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification under s.3 Land Customs Act appoints listed Rajasthan police officers as Land Customs Officers for areas adjoining West Pakistan frontier within jurisdiction of Collector Land Customs Delhi; jurisdiction spans multiple states/districts; schedule specifies officers not operational areas; plain words and purpose reject restricted 'adjoining' or district-limit interpretations.

holdings.text: Lal Singh had authority to seize the gold at the place where the seizure was made, and that s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act applied

anchor.surface_text: It was also of the opinion that Lal Singh had authority to seize the gold at the place where the seizure was made, and that s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act applied. In the opinion of the High Court, the accused had failed to prove that the gold was not smuggled and that under the provisions of s. 178-A as also on the evidence in the case, the gold had been established to be smuggled gold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seizure by authorized Land Customs Officer triggers s.178A reverse burden; High Court finding on authority upheld; accused failed to prove gold not smuggled, establishing it as smuggled on evidence and provision.

holdings.text: in consequence of the provisions of s. 178-A the accused has not tried to discharge the burden that lay on him that the gold was not smuggled that he was carrying smuggled gold

anchor.surface_text: s. 178-A the accused has not tried to discharge the burden that lay on him that the gold was not smuggled that he was carrying smuggled gold, the circumstances under which the gold was discovered, the manner in which he was carrying the gold, the considerable quantity of the gold that was being carried and the form in which gold was being carried, namely, blocks and bars in which the major portion of the gold was found, all these circumstances establish beyond a shadow of doubt that accused was carrying the gold knowingly and with the intention of evading the prohibition that was in force with respect to the import of gold into the country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accused did not discharge reverse burden under s.178A to prove gold not smuggled; failure leads to finding of smuggled gold.

holdings.text: all these circumstances establish beyond a shadow of doubt that accused was carrying the gold knowingly and with the intention of evading the prohibition that was in force with respect to the import of gold into the country

anchor.surface_text: all these circumstances establish beyond a shadow of doubt that accused was carrying the gold knowingly and with the intention of evading the prohibition that was in force with respect to the import of gold into the country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post s.178A smuggling finding, circumstances of concealment in pouli under trousers, large quantity (286 tolas ~3kg), form (blocks/bars), accused's modest railway pointsman position prove knowing possession and intent to evade import ban; s.178A does not directly prove mens rea but enables inference.

holdings.text: the High Court has rightly held that all the ingredients of the offence under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act have been established

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court has rightly held that all the ingredients of the offence under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act have been established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seizure by authorized officer in reasonable belief of smuggled goods proved; gold smuggled per s.178A; mens rea from circumstances; undisputed that recovery facts suffice for reasonable belief.

holdings.text: the circumstances are sufficient to establish that Lal Singh seized the gold in the reasonable belief that these were smuggled goods

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that it has not been disputed before us that if we believe the story of the recovery of the gold from the appellant, the circumstances are sufficient to establish that Lal Singh seized the gold in the reasonable belief that these were smuggled goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed by parties that proved recovery facts establish officer's reasonable belief of smuggling required for s.167(81).

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of Lal Singhs evidence along with the evidence of appellants own witness, Poonam Chand we are convinced that the story of recovery of gold from the accused is true.
In our opinion, the High Court has rightly held that all the ingredients of the offence under s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act have been established.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the construction put by the High Court on the notification is right, and Lai Singh, being an officer in the District of Barmer which is mentioned in the Schedule, was an officer for the entire area which formed the jurisdiction of the Collector of Land Customs, Delhi, including the place where the seizure was made, and was therefore competent to make the seizure.

anchor.surface_text: It was also of the opinion that Lal Singh had authority to seize the gold at the place where the seizure was made, and that s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act applied. In the opinion of the High Court, the accused had failed to prove that the gold was not smuggled and that under the provisions of s. 178-A as also on the evidence in the case, the gold had been established to be smuggled gold.
In our opinion, the High Court has rightly held that all the ingredients of the offence under s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act have been established.

anchor.surface_text: s. 178-A the accused has not tried to discharge the burden that lay on him that the gold was not smuggled that he was carrying smuggled gold, the circumstances under which the gold was discovered, the manner in which he was carrying the gold, the considerable quantity of the gold that was being carried and the form in which gold was being carried, namely, blocks and bars in which the major portion of the gold was found, all these circumstances establish beyond a shadow of doubt that accused was carrying the gold knowingly and with the intention of evading the prohibition that was in force with respect to the import of gold into the country.
In our opinion, the High Court has rightly held that all the ingredients of the offence under s. 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act have been established.
